### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Install PowerShell 7.2.0 from the package here: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v7.2.0/powershell_7.2.0-1.deb_amd64.deb .
2. Start it (`pwsh`).
3. Try to go up in history (arrow up), or going left/right in a text line (left/right arrows).

### Expected behavior

Arrow keys up/down go up/down the history, arrow keys left/right navigate within the text line.


### Actual behavior

```console
PS /home> OAOAOAOAOAOAOAODODODOCOCOCOCOCOC
```
...Appears when the arrow keys are pressed.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
According to the answer in https://vi.stackexchange.com/a/15328:

> When you press `Up`, the terminal sends the sequence:
>
>- (if it's in normal mode) `CSI A`, where `CSI` means `Control Sequence Introducer` and is produced by `ESC [;` in caret notation, the >whole sequence is displayed as `^[[A`
>- (if it's in application mode) `SS3 A`, where `SS3` is described as `Single Shift Select of G3 Character Set` here, and is produced by `ESC O`; in caret notation, the whole sequence is displayed as `^[OA`

So, it looks your terminal is in application mode for some reason.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
Interesting, PS 7.1.5 and PS 7.2 both ship the 2.1.0 version of PSReadLine module, so it's not because of the PSReadLine module.
PS 7.1.5 uses .NET 5 while PS 7.2 uses .NET 6. I suspect something is changed in `Console.ReadKey`. Can you please **try `[System.Console]::ReadKey($true)` and press `UpArrow`** in both PS 7.1.5 and PS 7.2 and share the results here?

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
> So, it looks your terminal is in application mode for some reason.

Actually, .NET requires application mode to support Arrow key escape sequences. So being in application mode is expected.
Run out of clues at this point ... Can you try the [PS 7.2.1](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.2.1) that was released yesterday? It's on top of .NET 6.0.1.

comments.author: chaplina
comments.body:
I was having this same issue.  I ssh to the Oracle Enterprise Linux 7 host from my PC using urxvt and the TERM is set to rxvt.

I decided to export TERM=xterm and run pwsh and the command recall using arrow keys started to work again.

Since this was working fine pre 7.2 I'd consider this a bug. :)

comments.author: blochl
comments.body:
Indeed! Just as @chaplina said!
I use the rxvt-unicode terminal as my main terminal, and it worked fine with PS 7.1.x. Now, with 7.2.x, I must run `TERM=xterm-256color pwsh` for the arrows to work.

Thanks, @chaplina , for the workaround.

And it does look like a bug / regression.
